7 # . OWL2 [https://www.w3.org/TR/owl2-primer/]

135 e term : jsonlditem
136 tag @
137 # The `@` tag has nothing to do with the JSON-LD reserved word prefix.
138 # Core wizzi schemas often use tha `@` tag symbol to indicate object properties (key-values).
139 # A `term` element is a key-value pair (property) in a `nodeObject` or `context` element.
140 # The key is a short-hand string that expands to an IRI or a blank node identifier.
141 # If the `term` element has children elements the `wzName` is the key and
142 # the child or children are the value. If it has no children the `wzName` is
143 # splitted in a key and a value pair separated by the first blank char.
144 # In a `context` element keys define the term,
145 # and values are the IRIs associated with the term.
146 # In a `nodeObject` keys may expand to an absolute IRI using the active context,
147 # and values must be one of the following elements:
148 # `valueItem`, or
149 # `nodeObject`, or
150 # `valueObject`, or
151 # list or set `array`, or
152 # an array of zero or more of the possibilities above, or
153 # `languageMap`, or
154 # `indexMap`
155 a id

157 # When the parent is a `nodeObject` the 'id' attribute
158 # means: 'This value is an identifier that is an IRI'

1 group
2 #
3 # Retrieve an ArtifactGenerator by its name
4 # Generators are searched in this WizziPackage
5 # No search up in "node_modules" folders.
6 m getArtifactGenerator
7 string generationName
8 +
9 var generator = this.artifactGenerators[generationName] || null
10 if generator == null
11 var modulePath
12 _ path.resolve
13 @ __dirname
14 @ './lib/artifacts/' + generationName + '/gen/main.js'
15 if this.file.exists(modulePath)
16 try
17 set generator = require('./lib/artifacts/' + generationName + '/gen/main')
18 catch ex
19 return
20 _ error
21 @ 'WizziPluginError'
22 @ 'getArtifactGenerator'
23 @ 'Error loading artifact generator: ' + modulePath + ', in plugin: ' + this.getFilename() + ', err: ' + ex.message + ', stack: ' + ex.stack
24 set this.artifactGenerators[generationName] = generator
25 return generator

1 wfschema model1
2 #
3 # The 'model1' schema defines a simple tree structure.
4 # It has 2 elements:
5 # . 'model1', the root.
6 # . 'item', the node.
7 # Both may contain children 'item' elements.
8 # Every element has a name (the ittf node value).
9 # 'item' elements have an 'order' attribute of type integer.
10 #
11 # In the generated javascript classes each element will have the properties:
12 # . wzParent
13 # . wzElement (the name of the schema element: 'model1' or 'item')
14 # . wzTag (the ittf node name, in this case it will be equal to the wzElement property)
15 # . wzName (the ittf node value)
16 # . wzSourceLine (the file, row, col position of the element in the source ittf document)
17 #
18 # The 'item' element will have also the property
19 # . order
20 #
21 e model1
22 is-root
23 r item/s
24 e item
25 a order
26 type integer
27 r item/s
28 e dummy : item
29 # {wfjobGlobalContextCheck}

1 md
2 include readme_vars
3 h2 Wizzi jobs
4 p The task runner of the wizzi factory.
5 h3 Reference
6 p
7 a Concept
8 href {url_concepts}#concept-8
9 span   |  
10 a Docs
11 href {url_docs}/jobs.html
12 span   |  
13 a Demo ittf source
14 href {url_demo_ittf_source}/advanced/essentials/filesystem/jobs
15 h3 Demo samples level-0
16 table
17 demo_step( 1)
18 p How to generate a javascript module from a single ittf document of schema `js`
19 demo_step( 2)
20 p How to generate a set of javascript modules from a set of ittf documents of schema `js`.
21 p The `src` attribute of the `artifact` elements contains a `glob` pattern.
22 h3 Demo samples level-1
23 table
24 demo_step( 1)
25 p How to execute a wizzi job to generate the artifacts for a new wizzi model schema from a wizzi model of schema `wfschema`.
26 demo_step( 2)
27 p How to executes a wizzi job that contains the request to execute other wizzi jobs.
28 h3 Demo samples level-2
29 table
30 demo_step( 1)
31 p How to execute a wizzi job that loads and generate modules of the language schema `js`.
32 demo_step( 2)
33 p How to execute a wizzi job that loads and generate documents of the language schema `html`.
34 demo_step( 3)
35 p How to execute a wizzi job that loads and generate documents of the builtin (noschema) `ittf`.
36 demo_step( 4)
37 p How to execute a wizzi job that loads and generate documents of the builtin schema `xml`.
38 demo_step( 5)
39 p How to execute a wizzi job that loads and generate documents of the builtin schema `json`.
40 demo_step( 6)
41 p How to execute a wizzi job that loads and generate documents of the builtin schema `text`.
42 h3 Demo samples level-3
43 table
44 demo_step( 1)
45 p How to generate a collection of artifacts from a collection property of a wizzi model.
46 h3 Wizzi factory generations
47 p All the packages of the wizzi factory are generated by wizzi jobs.

1 wfschema sample_0_1
2 # Wizzi schema: sample_0_1
3 #
4 # Our first schema has a `root` and a single `element`
5 # that could represent a product record information.
6 #
7 # Example
8 #
9 # sample_0_1
10 #
11 # item AlphaCPU 365
12 # id 3789
13 # category hw
14 # price 140
15 #
16 # item BetaCPU 528
17 # id 3891
18 # category hw
19 # price 270
20 #
21 export-to json
22 # This will add the method toJson() on every node object
23 # of the wizzi model that will be generated
24 e sample_0_1
25 # This is the `root element`.
26 # Its a good practice to give to the `root element`
27 # the same name of the `schema`.
28 is-root
29 # In this case, this is redundant.
30 # The first element declared in a schema is the root element,
31 # if no other node is marked with the flag `is-root`.
32 a currency
33 # The currency `attribute` can be used to declare
34 # the currency of price values. The default is dollar and
35 # is restricted to dollars and euros.
36 default
37 restrict
38 enum
39 # dollar
40 enum
41 # euro
42 r productItem/s
43 #
44 # The `root element` may contain productItem elements.
45 # The relation `one-to-many` is the default.
46 # The cardinality always is: `one-to-zero-or-many`.
47 # The other possible relation is `one-to-one` (must be declared).
48 # Example:
49 # r productItem
50 # one-to-one
51 # In the generated javascript class of the `root element` this
52 # declaration will produce the collection property: productItems.
53 #
54 e productItem
55 #
56 # The product item `element`.
57 # The `ittf node value` will contain the product name.
58 # This must be said in the `element` comment in this way:
59 # `The wzName is the product name.`
60 # `wzName` is the name of the `ittf node value` property
61 # in the generated javascript class that rapresent an `element`.
62 #
63 tag item
64 # The default `ittf node tag` of an `element` is its name, but is can
65 # be changed declaring a `tag` `attribute.
66 # Example of a productItem:
67 #
68 # item AlphaCPU 365
69 # id 3789
70 # category hw
71 # price 140
72 #
73 a id
74 # The product id (of type integer).
75 # The other types are: string (default), boolean, float, date.
76 type integer
77 a category
78 # The product category, that is restricted to
79 # hardware or software items.
80 restrict
81 enum sw
82 # software product
83 enum hw
84 # hardware product
85 a price
86 # The item price (of type float). The currency is declared in
87 # the `root node`.
88 type float
89 a dummy_for_testing context
90 # This attribute is for testing the model load context and
91 # the global context options.
92 # In the generated wizzi model the following comment lines for this attribute
93 # should be replaced by the values of the model and global context parameters.
94 # This line comes from the model load context: {modelLoadContextDummy}
95 # This line comes from the global context: {globalContextDummy}

1 wfschema sample_0_2
2 # Wizzi schema: sample_0_2
3 #
4 # In the second schema we implement a very common pattern
5 # used mainly in language schemas: a tree node structure
6 # without depth limits. Each node may have comments,
7 # free elements declared using the tag `<` and sub nodes and
8 # free attributes declared using the tag `@`.
9 #
10 # Example
11 #
12 # sample_0_2
13 #
14 # < alfa
15 # # An alfa node for ...
16 # @ id 1
17 # < beta
18 # @ size 5
19 # < gamma
20 # @ id 3
21 # < sigma
22 # @ height 4
23 # < tau
24 # @ id 5
25 # < delta
26 # @ id 6
27 #
28 export-to json
29 # This will add the method toJson() on every node object
30 # of the wizzi model that will be generated
31 e comment
32 # The comment `element`.
33 # The `wzName` will contain a comment line.
34 tag #
35 e attribute
36 # The attribute `element`.
37 # The attribute name is free.
38 # The `wzName` will contain a name value pair separated by a blank character.
39 tag @
40 e node
41 # The node `element`.
42 # We declare a node `element` that may contain many
43 # node elements in a relation `one-to-many` (default).
44 # So any node may contain nodes without depth limits.
45 tag <
46 r comment/s
47 # Node comment lines. Relation `one-to-many` (default)
48 r attribute/s
49 # Node attributes. Relation `one-to-many` (default)
50 r node/s
51 # Node sub nodes. Relation `one-to-many` (default)
52 e sample_0_2 : node
53 # The `root node` is derived from the node `element`.
54 # So the root too may contain comments, attributes and sub nodes.
55 is-root

1 wfschema sample_0_3
2 # Wizzi schema: sample_0_3
3 #
4 # In the third sample we try to implement a schema
5 # with some usefullness.
6 # A schema that can be used for describing API schema objects in
7 # requests, responses, operation parameters.
8 #
9 # This schema is inspired by
10 # the OpenAPI Specification Version 3.0.0 [https://swagger.io/specification/]
11 # a spec licensed under The Apache License, Version 2.0.
12 #
13 export-to json
14 e comment
15 # The comment `element`.
16 # The `wzName` will contain a comment line.
17 tag #
18 r comment/s
19 # Allow nesting of comment lines.
20 e commentable
21 # An abstract element that accepts children comment elements
22 # and is the base element of any element of this schema.
23 is-abstract
24 r comment/s
25 e sample_0_3 : commentable
26 # The `root node`.
27 # Contains a collection of named schema objects.
28 is-root
29 r schemaObject/s
30 # List of named schema object.
31 e schemaObject : commentable
32 # From Swagger definition
33 # `The Schema Object allows the definition of input and output data types.
34 # These types can be objects, but also primitives and arrays.`
35 #
36 # The `wzName` contains the name of the schemaObject.
37 tag schema
38 r datatype
39 # A schemaObject is composed by one datatype, typically
40 # an object or an array.
41 one-to-one
42 r discriminator
43 # When the schema datatype is a combinator
44 # element (oneOf, allOf, anyOf )
45 # The discriminator points to the property that specifies
46 # the data type name.
47 one-to-one
48 e datatype : commentable
49 # An abstract element from which all datatypes are derived.
50 # Derived elements, when their parent element is an object
51 # datatype, are object properties, and the `wzName` contains

137 # The `@` tag has nothing to do with the JSON-LD reserved word prefix.
138 # Core wizzi schemas often use tha `@` tag symbol to indicate object properties (key-values).
139 # A `term` element is a key-value pair (property) in a `nodeObject` or `context` element.
140 # The key is a short-hand string that expands to an IRI or a blank node identifier.
141 # If the `term` element has children elements the `wzName` is the key and
142 # the child or children are the value. If it has no children the `wzName` is
143 # splitted in a key and a value pair separated by the first blank char.

146 # In a `nodeObject` keys may expand to an absolute IRI using the active context,

8 - The basic grid contains just a few elements
9 - . container

13 - The width of the container is generally 100%,

18 - Using the 'border-box' model, we can create gutters with ease.

28 clear both
29 - To prevent that empty columns will stack on top of each other

31 < [class*='gsf-col-']
32 float left
33 min-height 1px
34 - our gutter
35 padding {gutter}px
36 - To find the width of one column, all we have to do is divide
37 - the total number of columns by the width of the container.
38 - In our case, the width of the container is {percWidth}%,
39 - and we want {columns} columns, so {percWidth}/{columns} = {percWidth/columns}%.

27 h2 Usefulness of cats
28 class gs-1-subhead
29 . gs-1-content
30 p In our urban and suburban houses what should we do without cats? In our sitting or bedrooms, our libraries, in our kitchens and storerooms, our farms, barns, and rickyards, in our docks, our granaries, our ships, and our wharves, in our corn markets, meat markets, and other places too numerous to mention, how useful they are! In our ships, however, the rats oft set them at defiance; still they are of great service.
31 p How wonderfully patient is the cat when watching for rats or mice, awaiting their egress from their place of refuge or that which is their home! How well Shakespeare in Pericles, Act iii., describes this keen attention of the cat to its natural pursuit!
32 blockquote
33 p The cat, with eyne of burning coal, Now crouches from (before) the mouse's hole.
34 blockquote
35 class gs-1-quote
36 p Let any one have a plague of rats and mice, as I once had, and let them be delivered therefrom by cats, as I was, and they will have a lasting and kind regard for them.

1 module
2 kind jsfile
3
4 /* required by examples */
5 var isUpperCaseRequired = false;
6 #
7 # Rationale
8 #
9 # Ittf documents are, at the same time, templates and lego brick pieces.
10 # Every node of an ittf document is computable and composable.
11 # It may contain, be the result of, be the starting point of, a computation
12 # or a composition.
13 # To 'alberize', render in indented tree format, a javascript
14 # source code greatly simplifies the brick composition of a module,
15 # at the cost of a little weird coding style that is easy to get
16 # acquainted of.
17 # The biggest cost, at the moment, is the lack of syntax highlighting and
18 # code completion, but Wizzi studio is under way and it will
19 # make up for that.
20 #
21 #
22 # In many cases you can choose how much to 'alberize' a statement.
23 # This statement ...
24 var myLetters
25 _ 'a, b, c'.split
26 @ '.'
27 ._ trim
28 ._ toUpperCase
29 # ... can be written without indentation
30 var myLetters = 'a, b, c'.split('.').trim().toUpperCase()
31 # Sometimes it is a matter of style and personal preference.
32 # Other times an indentation is required when templating. Imagine that upper case
33 # be a design choice in differentent scenarios.
34 # You could write ...
35 var myLetters
36 _ 'a, b, c'.split
37 @ '.'
38 ._ trim
39 if isUpperCaseRequired
40 ._ toUpperCase
41 # A deep indentation allow a template decision on every node
42 # of the AST.
43 include declarations
44 include objects
45 include expressions
46 include conditionals
47 include iterations
48 include exceptions
49 include functions
50 include classes
51 include debug
52 include test

1 module
2 kind react
3 #
4 # React module kind
5 #
6 # The wizzi factory is language and framework agnostic.
7 # It is a manipulator, transformer and composer of text documents,
8 # to whose semantics it is indifferent.
9 # The plugins are those that target specific domains.
10 #
11 # To came to life, and became an application, the wizzi factory
12 # has chosen a few target domains, first of all: nodejs, javascript, html,
13 # style sheets, and has implemented some core plugins, that are
14 # the starters of the factory.
15 #
16 # A fundamental component of the wizzi factory application, which development
17 # is under way, is the Wizzi studio web application. For the UI of
18 # Wizzi studio the React framework has been chosen.
19 #
20 # The 'js' wizzi schema, implemented by the wizzi-js plugin, contains elements
21 # taylored for the React framework.
22 #
23 #
24 # This module kind supports the new javascript synthax and React jsx.
25 # The generated source must be transpiled using Babel.
26 #
27 include component
28 include container

1 md

4 a

9 @ width 450
10 @ src https://wizzifactory.github.io/images/logo.svg

12 h1 Wizzi demo
13 p The official examples to get started with the wizzi factory.
14 h2 Installation
15 p The wizzi demo is available as an [npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/wizzi-demo).
16 sh
17 + npm install wizzi-demo
18 p A setup script must be run.
19 sh
20 + npm run setup
21 h2 Usage
22 sh
23 + node index all|se|sa|ae|ap
24 + # se = starter-essentials
25 + # sa = starter-apps
26 + # ae = advanced-essentials
27 + # ap = advanced-plugins
28 h2 Starter
29 p These examples use the default factory for a quick start.
30 p The default factory is an internally configured factory, that uses a `filesystem` store and has three pre-loaded plugins: `wizzi-core`, `wizzi-js` and `wizzi-web`. It is a starter factory to play with, that targets common web technologies.
31 h3 Essentials
32 p Contains [examples](https://github.com/wizzifactory/wizzi-demo/tree/master/starter/essentials) of essential methods of the wizzi factory API.
33 h3 Apps
34 p Contains [examples](https://github.com/wizzifactory/wizzi-demo/tree/master/starter/apps) of using the default factory to build react/redux single page apps.
35 h2 Advanced
36 h3 Essentials
37 p [This section](https://github.com/wizzifactory/wizzi-demo/tree/master/advanced/essentials) shows how to configure a wizzi factory instance with plugins and document stores of your choice, to accomplish essential tasks.
38 p You will use the `filesystem`, `mongodb` and `jsonfs` document stores.
39 h4 Plugins
40 p Explains how to create new [plugins](https://github.com/wizzifactory/wizzi-demo/tree/master/advanced/plugins).
